metadata.title: TN3164: Debugging the synchronization of NSPersistentCloudKitContainer

inlineContent.text: When you use
to manage a CloudKit-backed Core Data store, the store lives on the device to provide data to your app, the CloudKit database lives on the remote CloudKit server to hold the server truth, and
synchronizes them by
exporting
the local changes from the store to the database, and
importing
the remote changes from the database to the store. For more information about
, see

A synchronization failure can happen because of a code-level issue in your data presentation layer, a configuration issue related to CloudKit, or a limit on the system side. To debug a synchronization issue, look into the system logs in Xcode console or a sysdiagnose, then identify the relevant errors. This technote describes how to identify and resolve common errors seen in the logs when working with
The system determines when to synchronize data. When you save data to your Core Data store,

asks the system if it can export the changes; the export only proceeds after the system allows. Similarly, when getting notified of a change on a CloudKit private or shared database, it needs the system’s approval to execute an import.
A CloudKit public database doesn’t support database change notifications. When working with a CloudKit public database,
needs to poll periodically for the database changes. To avoid draining the system resources,

typically polls once every 30 minutes when working in the CloudKit development environment (to facilitate debugging), and up to once every 24 hours in the production environment. For more information, see WWDC20 session 10650:

inlineContent.overridingTitle: Sync a Core Data store with the CloudKit public database

overridingTitleInlineContent.text: Sync a Core Data store with the CloudKit public database

inlineContent.text: The goal of implementing such a mechanism is to balance the use of system resources and achieve the best overall user experience on the devices. There is no API for apps to configure the timing for the synchronization.
When your data synchronizes but not immediately, it is most likely that the system intentionally defers the synchronization. To discover what really happens inside an export or import, see
and

When your app doesn’t show the changes the other peer exported to the CloudKit database, it can be that the data is synchronized but your app’s UI is not refreshed. To verify if that is your case, quit your app, relaunch it, and confirm that the data is now up-to-date.
may import data while an app is launching. If relaunching your app causes synchronization, it may be that the system intentionally deferred the imports in the previous launch session. See
for more information.
synchronizes data when appropriate. To know the state of the synchronization, observe
. To get notified that
imported data to the store, observe
To keep your app’s UI up to date, consume the store’s persistent history when you get an
notification, merge the relevant changes to your
, and then refresh your app’s UI. Alternatively,
your
to clear the context cache, fetch the data, and then refresh your app’s UI.
For a sample that demonstrates how to observe the notifications and process the persistent history, see

inlineContent.overridingTitle: Sharing Core Data objects between iCloud users

overridingTitleInlineContent.text: Sharing Core Data objects between iCloud users

inlineContent.text: When working with a CloudKit public database,
doesn’t automatically synchronize object deletions because the database doesn’t support deletion tracking. To avoid presenting objects deleted by the other peer, consider the following strategy:
Add a new attribute to your Core Data entities to store the date when an object is removed.
When deleting an object, set its removal date to
, rather than really removing the object from the store. This converts the
to an
, which can be synchronized across devices.
In your app’s UI, only present the objects whose removal date is
If necessary, remove the objects whose removal date is sometime after the last successful export. The
sometime
needs to be long enough for the objects to be synchronized, which can be several months for apps that users use on a regular basis.
For more information, see WWDC20 session 10650:

inlineContent.overridingTitle: Sync a Core Data store with the CloudKit public database

overridingTitleInlineContent.text: Sync a Core Data store with the CloudKit public database

inlineContent.text: To synchronize data across devices via
, all the devices must have iCloud turn on for your app, and be logged in with an Apple ID. Perform the following steps to configure your devices:
Go to Settings > Apple ID > iCloud > Apps Using iCloud, find your app, and select the checkbox.

Log in the devices with an Apple ID. To synchronize a store associated with a CloudKit private database, log in the devices with a same Apple ID. For CloudKit sharing, log in the owner and participant devices with different Apple IDs.

When developing your app, if you see the synchronization works on some devices, but not on others, it may be that the CloudKit state cached on the device isn’t up to date. Perform the following steps to reset the cache:
Remove your app from the device.

Remove the Core Data store, if it still exists after step 1. On iOS and its variants, if the store is in an App Group container shared with other apps that need to stay, consider removing the store programmatically. On macOS, find the location of the store and remove it manually.
Log out iCloud on the device, log back in with the same Apple ID, and then reboot the device. This clears the cached state related to the Apple ID.
To use CloudKit in your app, follow the process described in

inlineContent.overridingTitle: Setting Up Core Data with CloudKit

overridingTitleInlineContent.text: Setting Up Core Data with CloudKit

inlineContent.text: to configure a CloudKit container. The process has Xcode automatically generate the appropriate entitlements for your app, and associate the container with your app ID, which allows your app to access the container.
When the association doesn’t exist,
hits a permission failure at run time, and generates logs with an error like the following example:

code: <NSCloudKitMirroringDelegate: …>: Found unknown error as part of a partial failure:
server message = "Invalid bundle ID for container"; … container ID = …>

inlineContent.text: For better readability, the logs in this technote are formatted to fit the page size, and some information in the logs is omitted.
To confirm that your CloudKit container and app ID are correctly associated:
Log in Apple’s
with your developer account, select the Certificates, Identifiers & Profiles page, and find the app ID of your app.
Click the app ID to navigate to the Capabilities page, confirm that iCloud is checked, then click Edit to navigate to the iCloud Container Assignment page.
Find your CloudKit container, and confirm that it is selected.
Refresh your provisioning profile. In Xcode, go to the Signing & Capabilities tab of your app target, un-select the
checkbox, select it again, and then
to have Xcode refresh the provisioning profile. If you use manual code signing, create the provisioning profile manually, and then download and install it to your Xcode.

If the portal shows that the association between your CloudKit container and app ID is correct, but the error still exists, it is most likely because the association isn’t synchronized to the CloudKit server. In that case, consider using a new CloudKit container to continue your development.
You can hide a CloudKit container using CloudKit Console, as shown in WWDC22 session 10115:
(the content starting at 1 minute), but can’t delete an existing container.
If your CloudKit container is already used in the production environment and switching to a new container leads to data loss, consider
filing a feedback report
with the following information to request manually associating your CloudKit container with your app ID:
The app ID and the CloudKit container that trigger the permission failure.
Screenshots that show the association between your CloudKit container and app ID in the developer portal.

content.text: Mirror your Core Data model to CloudKit

inlineContent.text: requires that an app’s Core Data model is completely mirrored to CloudKit. When detecting a Core Data attribute or relationship not existing in the CloudKit schema,
stops synchronization and generates logs like the following example:

code: because the mirroring delegate never successfully initialized due to error:
server message = "Cannot create or modify field '<A record field>' in record '<A record type>' in production schema"; …> …
because the mirroring delegate never successfully initialized due to error:
<CKError …: "Partial Failure" (2/1011); "Failed to modify some records"; … container ID = …;
server message = "Cannot create or modify field '<A record field>' in record '<A record type>' in production schema"; …

inlineContent.text: To completely mirror your Core Data model to CloudKit, see

CloudKit doesn’t support all the features of a Core Data model. When designing your model, avoid using the unsupported features, such as unique constraints and ordered relationships. For more information, see

inlineContent.overridingTitle: Creating a Core Data Model for CloudKit

overridingTitleInlineContent.text: Creating a Core Data Model for CloudKit

inlineContent.text: . For an example on how to avoid duplicates, see

If the debug build of your app synchronizes correctly but the App Store or TestFlight build doesn’t, it is most likely because you haven’t deployed your CloudKit schema to the production environment. For more information, see
CloudKit has some limits. For example:
The number of record zones in a CloudKit container is limited to 1000.
The number of record fields in a record type is limited to 256.
The size of a record is limited 1MB. (Record fields of the
type are excluded to this limit.)
The storage a user or an app can use is limited to its quota.
When your app hits a limit,
generates logs with a
error. Here is an example that happened because the record size was too large:

code: Called about a failure to save a share: <CKRecordID: …; recordName=cloudkit.zoneshare,

inlineContent.text: To avoid the 256 fields per record type limit, review your CloudKit schema. If you find a record type that is close to or exceeds the limit, trace back to the associated Core Data entity, and split it into multiple entities. See

inlineContent.overridingTitle: Reading CloudKit Records for Core Data

overridingTitleInlineContent.text: Reading CloudKit Records for Core Data

inlineContent.text: for how a Core Data model is mirrored to CloudKit.
For other limits, avoid them when designing your app’s architecture and workflow. If hitting a limit is inevitable, handle it appropriately. For example, whenever you create a new CloudKit share (
) using

, the API creates a new shared record zone. Over time, your app may hit the 1000 record zone per container limit. To avoid that, consider reusing an existing share when appropriate, and removing empty shares using
. In the case where your app inevitably hits the limit, provide an option the user to keep their data before removing a record zone.

content.text: Avoid synchronizing a store with multiple persistent containers

inlineContent.text: When using
to load a Core Data store that is already loaded by another
instance, you might see an error like the following example:

code: "CloudKit setup failed because there is another instance of this persistent store actively syncing with CloudKit in this process."
because there is another instance of this persistent store actively syncing with CloudKit in this process.,
NSUnderlyingException=Illegal attempt to register a second handler for activity identifier

inlineContent.text: This can happen when your app and extension both use

to manage a shared Core Data store (even though they are different processes). When working with an extension, you don’t control its lifecycle. It is perfectly possible that your extension is launched when your app is running, or vice versa, and both of them try to load the shared store.

To avoid the conflict, consider having the app in charge of the synchronization. An extension that has the capability to present UI can remind users to launch the app to synchronize with CloudKit, if that is an appropriate user experience.
The app and extension can avoid presenting stale data by observing
and consuming the persistent history, as discussed in
The error can also happen when your app unintentionally has multiple
instances that manage the same store. For example, when you set a variable that holds an
instance to a new value, the instance won’t be released if a Core Data object tied to the container still exists. To avoid the situation, release all the objects before releasing the
instance.

exports every change on the Core Data store to CloudKit. A lot of changes in a short time frame are converted to a high export rate. If the rate hits a limit, the system on the device or the CloudKit server may decide to defer the synchronization to avoid draining the resources. To determine if your app hits rate limit throttles, see
and

stops synchronization when hitting rate limit throttles, and automatically recovers when the throttles expire. The expiration time can be hours, and there is no API for your app to configure it. The strategy to handle rate limit throttles is to avoid them in the first place.

If your app hits the throttles, consider redesigning its architecture and workflow so it makes less changes in a longer time frame. For example, populating a large dataset in a short time frame to your Core Data store may trigger rate limit throttles, and you might be able to avoid that by separating the dataset in batches and populating them lazily, or by shipping the dataset as a local store, and then gradually moving the data to the CloudKit-back store if necessary. To manage multiple Core Data stores with a persistent container, see

inlineContent.overridingTitle: Linking Data Between Two Core Data Stores

overridingTitleInlineContent.text: Linking Data Between Two Core Data Stores

inlineContent.text: If your issue isn’t covered in the technote, consider figuring out what happens inside the synchronization process by tracing the exports and imports. For more information, see
First published.

Deletes all CloudKit records in the specified record zone, along with their corresponding managed objects.
Associates the specified managed objects with a new or existing share record.
Returns a date instance that represents the current date and time, at the moment of access.
A notification that posts after another process writes to a persistent store.

Discover how Core Data can help you adopt the CloudKit public database in your app with as little as one line of code. Learn how to easily manage the flow of data through your app and in and out of CloudKit. We’ll show you how to combine the complementary power of Core Data and the CloudKit public database to allow people to access — and contribute to — data, such as high scores or application templates. 

To familiarize yourself with the CloudKit Database, check out our “CKDatabase” documentation, and to learn more about CloudKit integration, read “Mirroring a Core Data Store with CloudKit.”

doc://com.apple.documentation/videos/pla.title: Sync a Core Data store with the CloudKit public database

abstract.text:
We’ll take you through the latest updates to CloudKit Console and discover how you can explore and debug your containers on the web like never before. Learn more about Act as iCloud, which helps you query records and view data from the perspective of another account. Discover how to share zones of records, and provide better collaboration between participants. And find out how to hide inactive containers. We’ll also share a few tips on getting the most out of CloudKit Console.

To get the most out of this session, we recommend having basic knowledge of CloudKit containers.
Learn about specific development topics through these in-depth technical articles.
